itemDescription: Keeper of Prints at the British Museum  (1792–1866)

wikipedia_page.main: William Hookham Carpenter (1792–1866) was a British antiquary, and Keeper of Prints at the British Museum.

response: *William Hookham Carpenter (1792–1866), Keeper at British Museum

In 1817, she married William Hookham Carpenter, Keeper of Prints and Drawings at the British Museum. Their children included two noted painters, another William and Percy Carpenter, who both travelled.The Golden Temple at Amritsar, William Carpenter, Feb. 1854, Victoria and Albert Museum, ref IS.50–1882, accessed July 2010 She introduced her sister Harriet to the young painter William Collins. They eventually married, making Margaret the aunt to Wilkie Collins, novelist and friend to Charles Dickens.The King of Inventors. Catherine Peters On her husband's death in 1866, she was given an annual pension of £100 by Queen Victoria. This award was partly based on her husband's service, but also in recognition of her own artistic merits.

link_mentions.page: List of people with surname Carpenter
response: * William Hookham Carpenter, 19th century Keeper at the British Museum

William Carpenter was born in about 1818. He was the eldest son of William Hookham Carpenter and his wife, Margaret Carpenter (born Geddes). His father was a keeper at the British Museum and his mother was a noted portrait artist. William entered the Royal Academy Schools in 1835.Indian Life and Landscapes by Western Artists, Pauline Rohatg et al, 2008, V&A, accessed July 2010 He initially painted with oils but quickly took to water colour.

Percy Carpenter (1820-1895), son of artists William Hookham Carpenter and Margaret Sarah Carpenter,National Portrait Gallery, London: Percy Carpenter portrait, 2010. was a painter active in the mid-19th century.
